audio_caption: A male speaker begins by stating he's not trying to look like Casey Neistat and introduces the topic of polarizing light. He explains that other channels cover the content, but he aims to help the listener get an A star.

The clip begins with an intense, cinematic, and slightly eerie musical score. A male speaker starts talking in an explanatory tone, detailing polarized sunglasses, their vertical polarizing filter, and their function to cut out horizontally polarized light. He mentions applications like skiing, watersports, driving, and reducing glare from cars and puddles. As he concludes, stating that these glasses cut out horizontally polarized light and mentioning the uses of polarization, the cinematic music swells back in, ending the clip.

A male speaker begins by describing a camera lens and a polarizing filter, explaining that the filter can control the amount of light transmitted through it by rotating one of the two filters. He then describes how rotating one of the filters by 90 degrees can cut out all of the light, acknowledging that this concept might be difficult to grasp and explaining that light oscillates in all planes around the direction of travel. The speaker then explains how we are used to seeing waves modeled like this with the wave just oscillating in one plane.

The clip begins with a calm, informative male speaker explaining that unpolarized light oscillates in all directions, and shows a model to illustrate the concept. The speaker then explains that polarized light oscillates in one plane. A brief musical interlude with a retro, synthwave feel and a slightly ominous tone is followed by the original male speaker describing a polarizing filter and its function in cutting out oscillations, emphasizing that plain polarized light means oscillation in only one plane. Another brief synthwave interlude comes in, before the speaker returns to explain the function of the filter model, allowing vertically polarized light through and blocking horizontally polarized light. The clip concludes with the speaker stating that this is the same process happening in polarizing filters in sunglasses.

The clip begins with a male speaker explaining how transverse waves can be polarized. He describes the usage of blue cones as emitters and receivers of 3 cm microwaves, and a grid acting as a polarizing filter. He describes how the detector reading changes with the orientation of the grid, going from maximum when horizontal to zero when vertical. He then comments on the detector reading with nothing in place. This is followed by the sound of something rattling.

The audio clip begins with speech from a single male speaker, discussing how a filter allows light waves to pass through in certain orientations while stopping others. A scraping sound then starts and becomes continuous. As the speaker continues, mentioning horizontal and vertical polarization, the scraping sound intensifies and becomes more rhythmic, akin to a percussive instrument.  A high-pitched dog-like bark can be heard while the speaker is talking. The bark disappears soon afterwards.

The audio begins with a male speaker explaining how unpolarized light can be turned into polarized light using a polarizing filter, emphasizing the filtering process that cuts out unwanted planes of oscillation. He speaks in an informative and clear tone. The recording seems to be in a quiet environment, then it transitions to only the speaker giving detailed explanation on light.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the function of filters, stating that by rotating a second filter, they can control the amount of light passing through a system of filters, a useful feature for detectors. He explains how unpolarized light is being polarized by one filter, and then absorbed by another polarizing filter. A second male speaker then explains the context as pertaining to a camera lens; with both polarizing filters oriented in the same direction, the front one polarizes the light, for example, into a horizontal direction, and the second filter allows that light through.

The clip starts with a male speaker describing how he's rotating the "front one" through 90 degrees, followed by an observation about light being cut out. He then mentions another rotation of 90 degrees, noting that more and more light is transmitted. The speaker concludes by saying "same again", followed by a short static sound. He summarizes the topic as "polarizing filters" before mentioning trying this out with an "awesome O Physics simulator," his tone informational throughout. The audio is accompanied by a consistent, low-volume ambient hum or background noise that remains constant from beginning to end.

A male speaker describes the features of a simulation, directing listeners to a link in the description. The speaker has an informative and enthusiastic tone, mentioning "unpolarized light," a filter that creates "vertically plane polarized light," and a second filter that can be rotated. The speaker then adds that as the filter rotates, the wave magnitude decreases with the cosine of the angle, finally saying "awesome simulations, go check them out!"

The clip begins with a single male speaker discussing polaroids and light, emphasizing "90 degrees," and "the orientation of the two." He explains the concept of light transmission being at a maximum when oriented in the same direction, and a minimum when one is at 90 degrees to the other. This shifts abruptly into the sound of a bicycle bell ringing rapidly and repetitively. This is followed by a brief musical interlude with a playful, somewhat ominous mood, reminiscent of a horror film score. The speaker returns, asking about the presence of "playing polaroids," suggesting a thematic connection to the opening discussion despite the abrupt shift in the audio environment.

The clip begins with a male speaker asking a question about the effect of rotating polarizing sunglasses on a light source, specifically asking if the light behind him is plane polarized. The speaker pauses as he receives a negative response. He acknowledges the response, stating that the light did not reduce in brightness and that the LEDs are not plane polarized. As he continues, the music begins. The music is an electronic style track featuring heavy bass.

The audio begins with a male speaker describing that "all the different colors have different polarizations," talking in an informative tone. He explains how 3D cinema works, using a similar concept, and then asks, "What about the computer screen?" Transitioning into an electronic, somewhat jazzy music track with a chill tone. Simultaneously, some subtle background ambience can be heard.

The clip begins with a single male speaker discussing polarization, mentioning that it "helps to kind of see it" and explaining polarization of horizontal surfaces. His tone is informative and somewhat educational. He transitions to describing why certain glasses are good for activities like skiing and driving, explaining that they cut out glare. A sound of something ruining a slinky occurs suddenly, interrupting the speech. The speaker then resumes his speech, encouraging viewers to subscribe and check out his website, in a friendly, encouraging tone, and asking for feedback. This is followed by a short piece of instrumental music, featuring a fast, electronic beat with a light, energetic mood. In the background, there is a steady ambient white noise throughout the clip.
